article.div: Key words and phrases:Extension dimension, [L]delimited-[]𝐿OPEN:[ italic-L CLOSE:][L]-homotopy

div.p: A new approach to dimension theory, based on notions of extension types of complexes and extension dimension leads to appearence of [L]delimited-[]𝐿OPEN:[ italic-L CLOSE:][L]-homotopy theory which, in turn, allows to introduce [L]delimited-[]𝐿OPEN:[ italic-L CLOSE:][L]-homotopy groups (see [1]). Perhaps the most natural problem related to [L]delimited-[]𝐿OPEN:[ italic-L CLOSE:][L]-homotopy groups is a problem of computation. It is necessary to point out that [L]delimited-[]𝐿OPEN:[ italic-L CLOSE:][L]-homotopy groups may differ from usual homotopy groups even for complexes.

More specifically the problem of computation can be stated as follows: describe [L]delimited-[]𝐿OPEN:[ italic-L CLOSE:][L]-homotopy groups of a space X𝑋italic-XX in terms of usual homotopy groups of X𝑋italic-XX and homotopy properties of complex L𝐿italic-LL.

The first step on this way is apparently computation of n𝑛italic-nn-th [L]delimited-[]𝐿OPEN:[ italic-L CLOSE:][L]-homotopy group of Snsuperscript𝑆𝑛italic-S POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endS^{n} for complex whose extension type lies between extension types of Snsuperscript𝑆𝑛italic-S POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endS^{n} and Sn+1superscript𝑆𝑛1italic-S POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-n ADDOP:plus NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endS^{n+1}.
In what follows we, in particular, perform this step.

Follow [1], we introduce notions of extension types of complexes, extension dimension, [L]delimited-[]𝐿OPEN:[ italic-L CLOSE:][L]-homotopy, [L]delimited-[]𝐿OPEN:[ italic-L CLOSE:][L]-homotopy groups and other related notions.
We also state Dranishnikov’s theorem, characterizing extension properties of complex [2].
All spaces are polish, all complexes are countable finitely-dominated C⁢W𝐶𝑊italic-C italic-WCW complexes.

For spaces X𝑋italic-XX and L𝐿italic-LL, the notation L∈AE(X)𝐿AE𝑋italic-L RELOP:element-of BIGOP:AE OPEN:( italic-X CLOSE:)L\in\mathop{\rm AE}\nolimits(X) means, that every map f:A→L:𝑓→𝐴𝐿italic-f METARELOP:colon italic-A ARROW:to italic-Lf:A\to L, defined on a closed subspace A𝐴italic-AA of X𝑋italic-XX, admits an extension f¯¯𝑓OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-f ARG:end\bar{f} over X𝑋italic-XX.

Let L𝐿italic-LL and K𝐾italic-KK be complexes. We say (see [1]) that L≤K𝐿𝐾italic-L RELOP:less-than-or-equals italic-KL\leq K if for each space X𝑋italic-XX from L∈AE(X)𝐿AE𝑋italic-L RELOP:element-of BIGOP:AE OPEN:( italic-X CLOSE:)L\in\mathop{\rm AE}\nolimits(X) follows K∈AE(X)𝐾AE𝑋italic-K RELOP:element-of BIGOP:AE OPEN:( italic-X CLOSE:)K\in\mathop{\rm AE}\nolimits(X). Equivalence classes of complexes with respect to this relation are called extension types. By [L]delimited-[]𝐿OPEN:[ italic-L CLOSE:][L] we denote extension type of L𝐿italic-LL.
